Dear Katrina Edmon:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation In the past, Staff 4 has made Youth A stand outside in the cold
without a coat or shoes on for a very long time.
Investigation Complainant was contacted twice on 2/5/2025 and a message
was left, however, the call was not returned.
Youth A was interviewed at the facility with MDHHS worker on
1/23/2025. Youth A reported that staff put the youth outside by
carrying them. Youth A did not recall the names of the staff
members. He stated Staff 4 has put him outside on an unknown
date. Youth A stated Youth D saw him getting put outside. Youth
A reported staff do not let the youth into the cottage when a youth
comes back from AWOL and makes them stand outside in the
cold without a coat or shoes. Youth A has told Director of
Residential Services and Staff 2 about the issues he’s been
having with Staff 4. Youth A stated on an unknown date, he went
AWOL and had to stay outside by an unknown staff member.
Youth A reported he does not like the facility, and he does not feel
safe.
Director of Residential Services was interviewed at the facility
with the MDHHS Worker on 1/23/2025. The Director of
Residential Services stated that there are times that a youth will
go outside without permission, and a staff member and that youth
will walk the oval sidewalk to debrief. She said when a youth
comes back from AWOL, they must be searched before they enter
the cottage. The youth are not outside and ignored. The youth are
not allowed to go outside in the cold without a coat and shoes.
She reported that Youth A only told her that he did not like Staff 4
because Staff 4 shows favoritism. Youth A did not report any other
issues with Staff 4.
2

Staff 1 was interviewed at the facility with MDHHS worker on
1/23/2025. Staff 1 reported she has not seen staff pick up youth
and put them outside nor has she ever seen youth standing
outside without proper clothing. She has seen youth walk out of
the cottages on their own and staff will follow them. Staff 1 also
reported that when a youth returns from AWOL, they are searched
inside of the cottages’ vestibule, and this lasts for 5-10 minutes.
Therapist was interviewed at the facility with MDHHS Worker
on 1/23/2025. Therapist stated she has not seen any staff put
youth outside and Youth A has never told her he was made to
stand outside without proper clothing. Youth A goals include
frustration tolerance and impulse control. There is a safety plan for
his triggers.
Director of Clinical Services was interviewed at the facility on
1/23/2025. Director of Clinical Services has not heard or seen any
staff physically put any youth outside in the cold without a coat or
shoes, and he has not witnessed or heard of staff refusing to allow
youth in the cottages upon returning from AWOL.
Youth B was interviewed at the facility with the MDHHS
worker on 1/23/2025. Youth B reported that youth are allowed to
come into the cottage upon returning from AWOL, but they have
to be searched first. He has never heard of any youth being made
to stand outside without proper clothing.
Staff 2 was interviewed at the facility with the MDDHS worker
on 1/23/2025. Staff 2 has not seen any staff members pick up
youth and place them outside and has never observed youth
forced to stand outside without proper clothing. He stated the
youth are allowed in the cottage after an AWOL.
Supervisor was interviewed at the facility with the MDHHS
worker on 1/23/2025. Supervisor has not seen youth picked up
and placed outside by staff nor observed youth forced to stand
outside without proper clothing. Youth are escorted outside for a
walk to separate them from the group when things escalate inside
of the cottage. When a youth goes AWOL, they are usually not at
the facility but stated the policy is for youth to be searched prior to
entering the cottage. He reported that he has worked shifts with
Staff 4 and he does not have any concerns.
Youth C was interviewed at the facility with MDHHS worker on
2/5/2025. He reported he likes being at the facility and he loves all
the staff. He reported when a youth AWOL’s, they are let back into
3

the cottage. He has never seen a youth stand outside in the cold
for punishment.
Youth D was interviewed at the facility with the MDHHS
worker on 2/5/2025. Youth D reported that he doesn’t like it at the
facility, and it is stupid, but he does not know why. Youth D stated
that he had to stand outside of the cottage once on an unknown
date but that was due to him not wanting to come back inside of
the cottage. He also stated he does not recall if Youth A told him
that a staff member made Youth A stand outside.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Incident reports dated 1/17/2025 written by Staff 4: Youth A
began yelling and cursing at staff. He walked up to staff
with his fist balled up as he was ready to fight. Youth A
walked out of the cottage without permission – staff
followed and located Youth A and took him to school.
• Unpaid administration leave email dated 1/24/2025 for Staff
4. The email stated that due to an open investigation, Staff
4 will be put on unpaid administration leave beginning
1/24/2025. Staff 4 is not to report to work, and the leave will
remain in effect into the conclusion of the investigation.
• Staff 4 Personnel file – 1 disciplinary record for
policy/procedure violation; not related to the allegations.
• Policies: Crisis Prevention Institution – Nonviolent Crisis
Intervention: Staff must use the Crisis Prevention Institute
method of intervention. The only reasons for physical
intervention – physical aggression toward another person,
physical aggression toward oneself, and gross property
destruction; MCHS Crisis Situation for CPI policies: Youth
Specialists are expected to remember to avoid overreaction
and under-reaction: using verbal intervention with a verbally
acting out person and physical intervention when a young
person escalates to physically acting out. All residential
staff are to de-escalate youth, not engage in a power
struggle and to only use physical intervention as a last
resort.
• Staff 4 Training log: CPI completed on 2/27/2024 and
2/28/2024. Role of the Youth Specialist completed on
2/29/2024.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff and youth
interviews, there is insufficient evidence to suggest that staff make
youth stand outside in the cold without a coat or shoes.
Conclusion Violation Not Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 4 pushed Youth A very hard and knocked him to the ground.
Investigation Complainant was contacted twice on 2/5/2025 and a message
was left, however, the call was not returned.
Youth A was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. On an unknown
date, Youth A reported he was inside Stoner Cottage when Staff 4
was restraining Youth C. Staff 4 told Youth A to go into his room,
but Youth A refused. Staff 4 then pushed Youth A to the ground
with one hand. Youth A reported that he fell to the ground and sat
there for a few minutes before getting up and running outside of
the cottage. Youth A reported the push did not hurt, he wasn’t
sore, and he didn’t have any marks or bruises. Youth A stated it
was the first time Staff 4 has done this to him, and she has not
pushed him since.
Director of Residential Services was interviewed with MDHHS
Worker during an unannounced visit to the facility on
1/23/2025. Director of Residential Services stated she does not
have any concerns with Staff 4 and other youth. Staff 4 appears to
care about the youth. She stated she is not aware of Staff 4
pushing Youth A.
Director of Clinical Services was interviewed with MDHHS
Worker at the facility on 1/23/2025. Director of Clinical Services
stated that he is not aware of Staff 4 pushing Youth A.
Staff 1 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Staff 1 stated
she does not work with Staff 4 and has not heard of Staff 4
mistreating youth. She explained the facility has a communication
book of what occurs throughout the day, and she does not recall
seeing written communication regarding staff pushing a youth in
the communication book. If a physical altercation were to occur
5

between a youth and staff, she would intervene, debrief/de-
escalate, and inform the supervisor.
Therapist was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Therapist
reported Youth A has not reported to her that Staff 4 pushed him.
She also reported Youth A has not disclosed that any staff have
physically assaulted him.
Director of Clinical Services was interviewed with MDHHS
Worker during an unannounced visit to the facility on
1/23/2025. Director of Clinical Services has never witnessed Staff
4 push Youth A to the ground.
Youth B was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025.
He stated staff have only pushed them lightly to separate a fight
during youth-on-youth incidents. Youth B reported he likes Staff 4,
and he has not seen anything inappropriate between Youth A and
Staff 4.
Staff 2 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Staff 2 stated he
has never seen Staff 4 be physical with any youth.
Supervisor was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
announced visit to the facility on 2/5/2025. Supervisor reported
he has no concerns with Staff 4 being physical with Youth A. He is
not aware of Staff 4 pushing Youth A and has never observed this
happening.
Youth C was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
announced visit to the facility on 2/5/2025. Youth C said he
likes Staff 4. He has not seen Staff 4 push youth or be mean to
them.
Youth D was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
announced visit to the facility on 2/5/2025. Youth D reported he
has not seen Staff 4 push Youth A.
Staff 3 was contacted with MDHHS Worker on 2/5/2025,
however, their mailbox was full, and the call was not returned.
Staff 4 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker over the phone
on 2/5/2025. Staff 4 reported Youth A and her had a great rapport
until Youth A felt like she was against him when he attacked
6

another resident. During that time, Youth A became angry and
started to see her as an enemy. Staff 4 stated on the day of the
incident, the ratio was 4:1, and the facility was out of ratio. Staff 4
reported Youth C came out of his room and said “fuck you” to
Youth B who was present. Youth C grabbed a hair pick and began
to threaten Staff 4 that he will stab her. Youth C began to throw
soap, and she requested him to go to his room.
Youth A came out of his room and said, “get the fuck off of him
and you not about to touch him”. Youth A was referring to Staff 4
restraining Youth C. Staff 4 asked Youth A to not walk towards her
while she was restraining Youth C. Staff 4 called a supervisor four
times and no one answered. She said Youth A walked towards
her with his fists balled up and Staff 4 reported that she felt as if
he was going to hit her and she moved him out of her way using
both of her arms, and in the process of moving Youth A from
potentially hitting her, Youth A fell but she didn’t physically push
him to the ground. Staff 4 also reported there needs to be
additional staff training with understanding the behaviors of the
children, crisis intervention and how to respond to a youth in a
medical crisis. She also reported staff do not have proper training
to deal with mental health and a child experiencing suicidal
ideations. She stated staff are supposed to call the police when a
child expresses suicidal thoughts, however, staff were told by
supervisors to not call as much because the facility is getting cited
by the Redford police department.
Please note, Staff 4’s allegations of being out of ratio were
investigated but did not produce additional violations.
Tour Observation:
A tour of the facility occurred on 1/23/2025. A walk through was
completed at Stoner cottage, in the hallway leading to Pod 7 and
Pod 8. Observed common area, bedrooms, kitchen area and there
were no concerns.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage provided by the facility on 1/24/2025. Video dated
1/17/2025 of Stone cottage hallway, please note there is no audio.
Youth B and C are seen running the hallway into the common
area, Youth B began to put his hands up and walked backwards
from Youth C. Staff 4 came into frame and walked towards both
youths. Staff 4 put Youth C’s arms behind him, and led him to a
wall, where Youth C’s body and face were touching the wall. Staff
4 continued to use each of her hands to hold each of Youth C’s
biceps behind his back. Youth B walked out of the frame and
7

Youth C was out of Staff 4’s restraint and as she grabbed him
again by his upper arms, there was a struggle with Youth C being
in the restraint. Youth C was wiggling his body around to get out of
the restraint. Youth A walked up to Youth C and Staff 4 and Staff 4
released Youth C out of the restraint and put her body very close
to Youth A’s body, as he was against a wall. Youth A pushed her
with both hands and Staff 4 and Youth A begin to push one
another. Youth A then falls to the ground with Staff 4 standing in
front of him.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Incident reports dated 1/17/2025 written by Staff 4: Youth A
began yelling and cursing at staff. He walked up to staff
with his fist balled up as he was ready to fight. Youth A
walked out of the cottage without permission – staff
followed and located Youth A and took him to school.
• Body chart for Youth A dated 1/24/2025 relating to the
1/17/25 incident: Youth A denied the RN to evaluate his
arms, legs and back. Youth A denied any scars, scratches,
cuts, bruise or injury to other locations of his body.
• Unpaid administration leave email dated 1/24/2025 for Staff
4. The email stated that due to an open investigation, Staff
4 will be put on unpaid administration leave beginning
1/24/2025. Staff 4 is not to report to work, and the leave will
remain in effect into the conclusion of the investigation.
• Staff 4 Personnel file – 1 disciplinary record for
policy/procedure violation; not related to the allegations.
• Crisis Prevention Institution – Nonviolent Crisis
Intervention: Staff must use the Crisis Prevention Institute
method of intervention. The only reasons for physical
intervention – physical aggression toward another person,
physical aggression toward oneself, and gross property
destruction; MCHS Crisis Situation for CPI policies: Youth
Specialists are expected to remember to avoid overreaction
and under-reaction: using verbal intervention with a verbally
acting out person and physical intervention when a young
person escalates to physically acting out. All residential
staff are to de-escalate youth, not engage in a power
struggle and to only use physical intervention as a last
resort.
• Staff 4 Training log: CPI completed on 2/27/2024 and
2/28/2024. Role of the Youth Specialist completed on
2/29/2024.
Analysis The agency is found in non-compliance as per youth interview and
video footage, there was evidence found that Staff 4 pushed
Youth A to the ground.
8

Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was provided regarding communication as
Staff 4 reported attempting to call for a supervisor, but her calls
were not answered timely. Timely and consistent communication
amongst all staff is essential for addressing any issues that arise,
such as unexpected ratio changes, escalating youth, etc.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or
discriminatory language including negative references to a youth's
background or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats,
ridicule, or humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Several staff members curse at Youth A and threaten him. No
further details of the names of the staff members are known.
Investigation Complainant was contacted twice on 2/5/2025 and a message
was left, however, the call was not returned.
Youth A was interviewed during an unannounced visit to the
facility on 1/23/2025. Youth A reported that unknown staff
members on unknown dates yell at the youth, talk about them in
the “wrong way” and are emotionally abusive. He also stated Staff
4 is rude and she has cursed at him, and other unknown staff
members curse and are rude to the youth. However, Youth A did
not provide further details of how staff talk about the youth in the
“wrong way”, staff cursing at youth or how Staff 4 is rude to him.
Director of Residential Services was interviewed during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Director of
Residential Services reported Youth A has not reported to her that
any staff yell at him. She reported staff may raise their voice to get
the youths’ attention, but she will address their tone of voice if she
is in the presence of a staff member raising their voice. She has
9

never heard staff curse; however, she would address it right away
with staff if this was ever heard.
Staff 1 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Staff 1 reported
she has not heard staff cursing at the youth or in general. Youth
have not reported to her of staff cursing at them.
Therapist was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Staff 2 reported
she did report to her direct supervisor, Director of Clinical
Services, and Director of Residential Services of Youth A
reporting staff yell at him. She does not recall his exact words as
she did not take notes of the conversation.
Director of Clinical Services was interviewed with MDHHS
Worker during an unannounced visit to the facility on
1/23/2025. Director of Clinical Services reported it was previously
brought to his attention of staff yelling and cursing at youth, but
the details are unknown. The facility has conducted team
meetings regarding appropriate ways to speak to youth. He has
never observed staff cursing at youth, but staff do raise their
voice.
Youth B was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Youth B
reported he overheard Staff 3 curse once and overheard
Supervisor curse a couple of times, but he apologized. Youth B
also reported staff do not curse at youth, but he has overheard
them when staff are in a conversation with one another. Youth B
did not provide further details of what Staff 3 and Supervisor said.
Staff 2 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Staff 2 reported
he has never observed or heard of any staff members yelling or
cursing towards any youth.
Supervisor was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
announced visit to the facility on 2/5/2025. Supervisor reported
he has encountered staff cursing around youth but not at them.
Supervisor admitted that he has cursed while having a
conversation with another staff member while youth are in the
vicinity but not at them. Supervisor did not provide details on what
he said around youth and if any youth has heard him.
10

Youth C was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
announced visit to the facility on 2/5/2025. Youth C reported
staff have never used inappropriate language towards himself and
he has never observed this happening towards other youth.
Staff 3 was contacted with MDHHS worker on 2/5/2025,
however, their mailbox was full, and the call was not returned.
Documents Reviewed:
• Relationship Building Policy: The policy discussed staff
having positive interactions with young people which is
essential for relationship building and establishing trust.
Staff will not use profanity or inappropriate language when
addressing young people, in reference to young people or
in any space that a young person can hear staff.
• Staff 4 Personnel file – 1 disciplinary record for
policy/procedure violation; not related to the allegations.
Analysis The facility was found in compliance as per interviews with youth
and staff, there was insufficient evidence found that staff members
cursed or threatened Youth A.
Technical Assistance The facility is advised to discuss ways to
help staff ensure that only appropriate language and
conversations occur around youth. Over the course of the
investigation, there was consistency in interviews with staff and
youth of staff using inappropriate language in the vicinity of the
youth.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4159 Youth restraint; pregnant youth; reduction,
Section prevention; prohibited restraints; elimination of restraints.
Description (5) In the event a restraint occurs, it must be performed in a
manner that is safe, appropriate, and proportionate to the severity
of the youth's behavior, chronological and developmental age,
size, gender, physical condition, medical condition, psychiatric
condition, and personal history, including any history of trauma,
and must be done in a manner consistent with the youth's
treatment plan.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff 4 inappropriately restrained Youth C.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
unannounced visit to the facility on 1/23/2025. Youth A
11

reported he did not go into his room when told by Staff 4 while she
was restraining Youth C. Then Staff 4 pushed Youth A to the
ground with one hand inside at Stoner cottage.
Youth C was interviewed with MDHHS Worker during an
announced visit to the facility on 2/5/2025. Youth C reported he
does not recall any incidents with Staff 4 and that he has not been
restrained by Staff 4. When asked about restraints being
performed in general, Youth C stated staff will put youths’ arms
behind their back to be restrained. Youth C did not provide any
other additional information.
Staff 4 was interviewed with MDHHS Worker via phone on
2/5/2025. She recalls restraining Youth C utilizing the CPI model.
She stated she used the restraint correctly as she took both of
Youth C’s arms and put them behind his back.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage provided by the facility on 1/24/2025. Video dated
1/17/2025 of Stone cottage hallway, please note there is no audio.
Youth B and C are seen running the hallway into the common
area, Youth B began to put his hands up and walked backwards
from Youth C. Staff 4 came into frame and walked towards both
youths. Staff 4 put Youth C’s arms behind him, and led him to a
wall, where Youth C’s body and face were touching the wall. Staff
4 continued to use each of her hands to hold each of Youth C’s
biceps behind his back.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Crisis Prevention Institution – Nonviolent Crisis
Intervention: Staff must use the Crisis Prevention Institute
method of intervention – the youth specialist should utilize
the young person’s control position. This position involves
staff gaining control of the youth’s arm by crossing the
youth arms in front and securing them, while also
maintaining close body contact and a balanced stance.
• Staff 4 Personnel file – 1 disciplinary record for
policy/procedure violation; not related to the allegations.
• Staff 4 Training log: CPI completed on 2/27/2024 and
2/28/2024. Role of the Youth Specialist completed on
2/29/2024.
Analysis Per video review, Staff 4 did not properly utilize the facilities CPI
restraint model to restrain Youth C. Staff 4 was holding Youth C’s
upper biceps behind his back, however, Staff 4 should have
gained control of Youth C’s arms from behind, crossing them in
front of his chest.
12

Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2024SIC0001698 dated 2/8/25, CAP Approved 3/14/25.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
